Figure Caption: EBSD-band contrast (BC) maps (left) and BC maps overlaid by inverse pole figure (IPF) maps (right) of the material after (a) hot rolling and homogenization and after (b) 10% cold rolling, (c) 25% cold rolling, and (d) 50% cold rolling. Substantial formation of deformation twins was observed after 50% cold rolling as shown in the inset of (d) in (e). White lines denote ∑3 (60°<111>) grain boundaries.

TEM bright field (BF) images of the material after 50% cold rolling. (a) The deformed microstructure is dominated by the occurrence of dislocation cells. (b) In addition, thick deformation twins are observed. These twins were found to contain a high density of dislocations (inset in (b)). The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern with [-110]γzone axis reveals the twin orientation relationship.
Schematic illustration of the ideal texture components and fibers formed in the alloy investigated, ODF sections at ϕ2= 0°, 45°, and 65°. The texture components are defined inTable 2.
Texture evolution of the investigated HEA during cold rolling, ODF sections at ϕ2= 0°, 45°, and 65°.
Volume fractions of the main texture components developed during cold rolling.
EBSD-BC maps overlaid by IPF maps of the material after 50% cold rolling and annealing for 1 h at (a) 600 °C, (b) 650 °C, (c) 700 °C, and (d) 900 °C.

TEM BF image of the material after 50% cold rolling and annealing at 650 °C for 1 h. The inset highlights a non-recrystallized matrix grain containing deformation twins surrounded by recrystallization nuclei. The SAED pattern with [-110]γzone axis was taken from the deformed matrix.
Texture evolution of the investigated HEA during annealing, ODF sections at ϕ2= 0°, 45°, and 65°.
Volume fractions of the main texture components developed during annealing of the 50% cold-rolled material.
(a) Engineering stress–strain curves and (b) true stress–true strain curves (dotted lines) and work-hardening rate–true strain curves (complete lines) of the investigated alloy.

TEM BF images of the material after 50% cold rolling and tensile testing until fracture. (a) A high density of fine deformation twins is formed during tensile testing (SAED pattern with [001]γzone axis). (b) Thicker deformation twins induced by cold rolling undergo secondary twinning during further deformation by tensile testing, as highlighted by the inset of (b).

TEM BF images of the material after 50% cold rolling, annealing at 650 °C for 1 h and tensile testing until fracture. (a) A high density of fine deformation twins formed in the non-recrystallized matrix during tension. (b) & (c) In contrast, the recrystallized grains did not undergo deformation twinning. The SAED pattern with [-110]γzone axis in (c) reveal that the recrystallized grain has a very similar orientation to the non-recrystallized matrix. Deformation twinning in recrystallized grains was only observed sparsely, as shown in the inset of (d).
Microhardness and texture-index evolution after 50% cold rolling and annealing for 1 h at varying temperature.

EBSD maps with IPF color-coding of the material after 50% cold rolling and annealing at 650 °C and 700 °C, respectively. The EBSD maps containing all grains were subdivided into maps of non-RX grains and RX grains based on the GROD-AO value of each grain. The corresponding microtexture ODFs are presented for constant φ2angles. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)
Orientations of first order twins (60°<111> orientation relation) with respect to the matrix texture components (a) Goss, (b) Goss/Brass, (c) Brass, and (d) P.

Simulated textures by the cellular automaton method considering (a) only orientations of primary twins formed by 60°<111> rotation of the 50% deformed grains (condition 50% inFig. 4), (b) only orientations of grains nucleating at grain boundaries; nuclei are considered to form with orientations close to the 50% deformed grains within a scatter of 5°, (c) consideration grain boundary nucleation and annealing twinning, (d) considering only the orientations extracted as recrystallized grains from experiments (condition 650 °C inFig. 14), ODF sections at ϕ2= 0°, 45°, and 65°.

(a) Work-hardening rate-true stress curve and (b) trues stress-strain (dotted line) and work-hardening rate-true strain curves (complete line) of the 50% cold-rolled and at 700 °C annealed material. A to E indicate different work-hardening regimes. The curves in (b) are shown up to a true plastic strain of 0.1. The complete curves are illustrated inFig. 10.
